title: Baldoyle Bay
text:
Baldoyle Bay is a sea <a href="inlet">inlet</a> on the east coast of <a href="Fingal">Fingal</a> in <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>, in the historic <a href="County%20Dublin">County Dublin</a>. It is situated between <a href="Portmarnock">Portmarnock</a>, at its head, and <a href="Baldoyle">Baldoyle</a>. It contains two small <a href="estuaries">estuaries</a>, those of the Sluice River and the Mayne River, and is sometimes called Baldoyle Estuary. The inlet is an important natural feature with protected status. It was once the site of a Viking "<a href="longphort">longphort</a>" and later the fishing village of Baldoyle developed near its outlet to the sea.
Location and access.
The narrow inlet runs north–south, reaching the sea north of <a href="Howth%20Head">Howth Head</a>, along the <a href="Burrow%20Beach">Burrow Beach</a>. At its head is Portmarnock Bridge, where a road from old Portmarnock meets the road from the modern <a href="Portmarnock">Portmarnock</a> village centre, while near its outlet is the former fishing village of <a href="Baldoyle">Baldoyle</a>, now a residential suburb of Dublin. It is bounded on the seaward side by the peninsula on which the Velvet Strand (used as a runway for early flights) and the <a href="Portmarnock%20Golf%20Club">Portmarnock Golf Club</a> course are situated. 
The estuary is paralleled by a coastal road to the west and north, served by bus, and with few possibilities for parking. To the east, access is possible on foot from parking for Portmarnock's southern beaches. A small green space exists at the northern end of the estuary. This is popular with birds and holds an interpretative sign with information on the area. There is also a walking route to the estuary from the <a href="Clongriffin">Clongriffin</a> area, across the former Baldoyle Racecourse.
Nature.
The inlet contains the estuaries of two small rivers, the Sluice at the northern, Portmarnock, end, and the Mayne, mid-way south, at the north end of Baldoyle. Each river is formed from several <a href="tributaries">tributaries</a> in mid-Fingal, and both cause flooding fairly regularly at certain points on their courses.
The inlet contains both freshwater and saltwater marshes, as well as raised <a href="salt%20marsh">salt marsh</a>, mud and sand, and riverine shallows and mud channels, and is protected by <a href="sand%20dune">sand dune</a>s. Four habitat types feature in Annex I of the EU <a href="Habitats%20Directive">Habitats Directive</a>, namely Salicornia mud, Mediterranean <a href="salt%20meadow">salt meadow</a>s, Atlantic salt meadows and tidal <a href="mudflat">mudflat</a>s. Much of the intertidal flats are exposed at low tide, mostly sand but also some muds in the inner estuary. 
Notable <a href="flora">flora</a> include common <a href="cord-grass">cord-grass</a>, narrow-leafed <a href="eelgrass">eelgrass</a>, dwarf eelgrass, and, in summer, green <a href="algae">algae</a>. In the salt marsh area, sea rush, sea purslane, sea plantain and glasswort are found.
Baldoyle Bay is an important coastal site, used by wintering wildfowl, including <a href="Brent%20geese">Brent geese</a>], and waders and other birds. Regularly sighted species included mallard duck, shelduck, great crested grebe, pintail, golden plover, redshank, bartailed godwit and the common scoter. <a href="Tubeworm">Tubeworm</a>s and <a href="Thalassinidea">mud shrimp</a>s can be found in the bay.
Designations.
The bay is a <a href="Special%20Protection%20Area">Special Protection Area</a>, cared for by the local authority and the <a href="National%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20Service%20%28Ireland%29">National Parks and Wildlife Service</a>. Declared a <a href="Law%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Ireland">Statutory</a> <a href="Nature%20Reserve">Nature Reserve</a> in 1988 the inner, estuarine, parts of the bay are protected as a <a href="Special%20Area%20of%20Conservation">Special Area of Conservation</a> (SAC) while, under the <a href="Ramsar%20Convention">Ramsar Convention</a>, the wetlands have been designated as of international importance. They support several habitats that are listed in the EU <a href="Habitats%20Directive">Habitats Directive</a>. It is part of the <a href="Dublin%20Bay%20Biosphere%20Reserve">Dublin Bay Biosphere Reserve</a>.
History.
The Baldoyle area was raided and later settled by the "dark-haired foreigners" (Danish Vikings), who found the bay convenient for their long-boats, with their shallow draft - the Mayne River and related streams provided fresh water. Their settlement was near what later became Baldoyle village, while Portmarnock formed on the Sluice River near the bay. In more recent times, north of Baldoyle village, was Baldoyle Racecourse, for a period Dublin's main racecourse, and later one of two major horse-racing venues.
